verses.text: Now when the holy city was inhabited with all peace, and the laws were kept very well, because of the godliness of Onias the high priest, and \add his\add* hatred of wickedness,
it came to pass that even the kings themselves did honour the place, and magnify the temple with \add their\add* best gifts;
insomuch that Seleucus king of Asia of his own revenues bare all the costs belonging to the service of the sacrifices.
But one Simon of the tribe of Benjamin, \add who was\add* made governor of the temple, fell out with the high priest about disorder in the city.
And when he could not overcome Onias, he gat him to Apollonius \add the son\add* of Thraseas, who then was governor of Coelosyria and Phenice,

and told \add him\add* that the treasury in Jerusalem was full of infinite sums of money, so that the multitude of \add their\add* riches, which did not pertain to the account of the sacrifices, was innumerable, and that it was possible to bring all into the king’s hand.

Now when Apollonius came to the king, and had shewed \add him\add* of the money whereof he was told, \add the king\add* chose out Heliodorus his treasurer, and sent \add him\add* with a commandment to bring \add him\add* the foresaid money.
So forthwith Heliodorus took \add his\add* journey, under a colour of visiting the cities of Coelosyria and Phenice, but indeed to fulfil the king’s purpose.

And when he was come to Jerusalem, and had been courteously received of the high priest of the city, he told \add him\add* what intelligence was given \add of the money\add*, and declared wherefore he came, and asked if these \add things\add* were so indeed.
Then the high priest told \add him\add* that there was such money laid up for the relief of widows and fatherless children:

and that some \add of it belonged\add* to Hircanus \add son\add* of Tobias, a man of great dignity, \add and\add* not as \add that\add* wicked Simon had misinformed: the sum \add whereof\add* in all \add was\add* four hundred talents of silver, and two hundred of gold:

and that it was altogether impossible that \add such\add* wrong should be done unto them, that had committed \add it\add* to the holiness of the place, and to the majesty and inviolable sanctity of the temple, honoured over all the world.
But Heliodorus, because of the king’s commandment given him, said, That in any wise it must be brought into the king’s \add treasury\add*.
So at the day which he appointed he entered in to order this matter: wherefore there was no small agony throughout the whole city.

But the priests, prostrating themselves before the altar in \add their\add* priests’ vestments, called unto heaven upon him that made a law concerning things given to be kept, that they should safely be preserved for such as had committed \add them\add* to be kept.

Then \add whoso\add* had looked the high priest in the face, it would have wounded \add his\add* heart: for \add his\add* countenance and the changing of \add his\add* colour declared the \add inward\add* agony of \add his\add* mind.
For the man was \add so\add* compassed with fear and horror of the body, that it was manifest to them that looked \add upon him\add*, what sorrow he had now in \add his\add* heart.
Others ran flocking out of \add their\add* houses to the general supplication, because the place was like to come into contempt.

And the women, girt with sackcloth under \add their\add* breasts, abounded in the streets, and the virgins that were kept in ran, some to the gates, and some to the walls, and others looked out of the windows.
And all, holding \add their\add* hands towards heaven, made supplication.
Then it would have pitied \add a man to see\add* the falling down of the multitude of all sorts, and the fear of the high priest, being in \add such\add* an agony.
They then called upon the Almighty Lord to keep the \add things\add* committed of trust safe and sure for those that had committed \add them\add*.
Nevertheless Heliodorus executed that which was decreed.

Now as he was there present himself with \add his\add* guard about the treasury, the Lord of spirits, and the Prince of all power, caused a great apparition, so that all that presumed to come in with \add him\add* were astonished at the power of God, and fainted, and were sore afraid.

For there appeared unto them a horse with a terrible rider upon him, and adorned with a very fair covering, and he ran fiercely, and smote at Heliodorus with his forefeet, and it seemed that he that sat upon \add the horse\add* had complete harness of gold.

Moreover two other young men appeared before him, notable in strength, excellent in beauty, and comely in apparel, who stood by \add him\add* on either side, and scourged him continually, and gave him many \add sore\add* stripes.
And \add Heliodorus\add* fell suddenly unto the ground, and was compassed with great darkness: but they \add that were with him\add* took \add him\add* up, and put \add him\add* into a litter.

\add Thus\add* him, that lately came with a great train and with all \add his\add* guard into the said treasury, they carried \add out\add*, being unable to help himself with \add his\add* weapons: and manifestly they acknowledged the power of God:
for he by the hand of God was cast down, and \add lay\add* speechless without all hope of life.

But they praised the Lord, that had miraculously honoured his own place: for the temple, which a little afore was full of fear and trouble, when the Almighty Lord appeared, was filled with joy and gladness.
Then straightways certain of Heliodorus’ friends prayed Onias, that \add he\add* would call upon the most High to grant him his life, who lay ready to give up the ghost.
So the high priest, suspecting lest the king should misconceive that some treachery had been done to Heliodorus by the Jews, offered a sacrifice for the health of the man.

Now as the high priest was making an atonement, the same young men in the same clothing appeared and stood \add beside\add* Heliodorus, saying, Give Onias the high priest great thanks, insomuch as for his sake the Lord hath granted thee life:
and seeing that thou hast been scourged from heaven, declare unto all \add men\add* the mighty power of God. And when they had spoken these \add words\add*, they appeared no \add more\add*.
So Heliodorus, after he had offered sacrifice unto the Lord, and made great vows unto him that had saved his life, and saluted Onias, returned with his host to the king.
Then testified he to all \add men\add* the works of the great God, which he had seen with his eyes.
And when the king asked Heliodorus, who might be a fit \add man\add* to be sent yet once \add again\add* to Jerusalem, he said,
If thou hast any enemy or traitor, send him thither, and thou shalt receive him well scourged, if he escape with his life: for in \add that\add* place, no doubt, there is an especial power of God.
For he that dwelleth in heaven hath his eye on that place, and defendeth \add it;\add* and he beateth and destroyeth them that come to hurt \add it\add*.
And the \add things\add* concerning Heliodorus, and the keeping of the treasury, fell out on this sort.
